text: very dear friend of mine was diagnosed
with breast cancer when she was about 29
they had done a mastectomy and removed
one of her breasts of course they had to
take her picture as a photographer it's
my way of documenting the things in my
life and the people in my life and maybe
it's how I come to terms with things
myself and she suggested that hey you
know maybe you'd find it interesting to
shoot some of these other young women
that I've gone through chemo with I shot
one and then another and then another
and then another and here we are eight
years later and I've shot
gosh close to a hundred young women
youngest being around seventeen breast
cancer at Weill we all think we're very
aware of it and we in our head we see
breast cancer as a pink ribbon most
people have never ever seen what it
looks like ever I think even less
well-known than these young women in
their teens and twenties having breast
cancer was men getting breast cancer men
often get breast cancer later in life
and so by the time these guys actually
go to the doctor it's often much more
advanced than a woman's might be first
of all a woman in general knows about
breast cancer and most men have no idea
that they could even get it
the Unknown Soldier is a series of much
like the scar project large-scale images
approximately five feet across they're
these very honest portraits of young men
and women coming back from Afghanistan
and Iraq who have been very very
seriously injured
they have no legs no arms melted faces
melted bodies blinded you can see
whatever's left of their legs whatever's
left of their arms whatever's left of
their face and it's a very honest
artifact often these returning warriors
who have been severely severely injured
they're shown you know either
running in the Paralympics or playing
wheelchair basketball or in their dress
clothes you know and looking quite
fantastic and well integrated and while
that's very true for a portion of them
there's also a really large portion of
them that don't do that that are
completely devastated by what's happened
to them I've received thousands and
thousands of emails they often start out
with something like I'm a 20 year old
woman I'm a fifty year old man I have
breast cancer I lost my legs in a car
accident I felt like a monster and they
look at the pictures and they think gosh
they're so beautiful these these women
or even the men in the Unknown Soldier
as as wounded as they are and I think
they think gosh if if I think they're
beautiful then and I look just like that
and then you know perhaps I'm beautiful
too
you
